We bought a car from one of David's coworkers with a contract stating $300 down and $900 more to follow. She didn't have the title to give us and had had a lien against the car that she'd paid back, but the company had since gone out of business. So while she was appealing to whomever you appeal to in such situations, we were driving a car with an expired tag for months- because you need a title to get a new tag. (David told her that if we got ticketed for having an expired tag, she was paying the fees.) So one day a month-or-so ago, she comes to work with the title and said if David didn't give her the last $300 that day, she was taking the car back (evidently she'd kept a key). So she did, and David called the cops and showed them the contract which did not stipulate time frame for payment. Small-claims court, they said. She tried to tell us we had no right to ask for the $900 we'd already paid, but the next day she admitted that she'd been wrong about that, and simply couldn't afford to give it back, so the car was still on the table if we could come up with the last payment. So my mother, my wonderful, thoughtful, caring mother who rocks gave us the money out of her tax return. Upon taking her the money, David learned that the car had been impounded because she decided that a good solution to having an expired tag was to just remove the plate altogether. It cost her $400 to get the car off the lot, so she had to use all of our last payment and $100 of her own besides. And the title is signed over to David. 

I'm caught between thinking that the car was meant to be impounded and isn't it a blessing it happened after she had reasserted possession so we were not out that money too, and feeling very smug. I'm trying to be more charitable in my thoughts.

Golly, this might take several installments! I guess I should start in chronological order, though that'll be difficult because what's happening now is so much better and more exciting than what came before. I've been hesitant to post because I didn't want to write about the bad, but didn't see anyway around it, and now I see I must tell about the things that suck so it will be clear just how much things are beginning to not suck now. Something I've learned in my recent wanderings is that you cannot gauge how far you've come until you turn around. 

When I first moved in with David, he and his friends Will and Little Dave had just recently opened their door to David's little brother, Kevin, futher crowding their tiny 2-bedroom apartment and cramping the style of untold numbers of cockroaches. Kevin was sleeping on one of the couches with his furniture and belongings in the dining room. I was quickly overwhelmed by the chore of cleaning up after four men, only Will having the same views on the necessity of cleanliness as I had. He was less than helpful, though, seeming to have little practical knowledge of how to get and keep things clean. I blame that on his wealthy upbringing and the indulgence parents often have for the messiness of their male children. He was going to throw away his bathroom rug when I took it from him, shook it out over the balcony and added it to the dirty clothes we were amassing for the trip to the washateria and asked him to humor me. The delight and amazement on his face when he pulled it, fluffy and bright, from the dryer filled me with despair that I was doomed to teach people older than I was things I learned when I was two. Welcome to the disposable generation. If it requires effort, throw it away. 

It was a relief when the end of the lease neared and we agreed to move into a bigger 4-bedroom apartment in the same complex. We all took the week off, wanting to move as soon as the management said the new place was ready. David asked everyday, and they finally handed him the keys on the last day of the lease and told us we had six hours to move. Then it started raining. The new apartment was missing the silverware basket in its dishwasher (which had broken racks) hanger poles in the closets, a fridge that opened the wrong way, and had several outlets that didn't work. We scavenged what we could from the old place and were grateful that we had fewer roaches (they negotiated with us for our food, instead of simply taking it). Kevin lost his job. I learned I was diabetic and a week before Christmas, I got the flu. I was so sick the first day, I was to weak to get out of the bed and became dehydrated because I could only stand long enough to go to the bathroom and drink water from my cupped hand. David was at work, and no one knew I was home. I was sick for weeks and my boss replaced me, though I kept him in the loop. I have since learned that people with diabetes have crappy immune systems and are supposed to get flu shots every year as soon as they're offered, since we are more likely to die from it. Then Will started coming up short for rent, though he made more than any of us. This, combined with his attitude of entitlement had us asking him to leave. 

When we were living in the small apartment, I had stood in the doorway to Little Dave's room, where he was worshiping his computer with his back to the door. As a joke, I lifted my shirt and flashed him. Right then he shouted "Yes! I just got 250 in Engineering!" Little Dave then wanted to know what the rest of us were laughing about. So one night after we moved into the big place, we were watching a movie and everyone else had gone to bed. Little Dave and I were watching the credits and he asked me if he could touch my breasts. Out of the blue. I said no as gently as I could. He asked why I had flashed him that time, and told him I did it because I knew he wouldn't turn around and I apologized for making a joke at his expense. I said I would've been mortified if he'd turned around, and I was sorry for any confusion I'd caused, but I was in love with David. He apologized for asking and I told him we were cool, and went to bed and told David. I later told Little Dave that if he'd asked while David was present it might have affected my answer. I stopped flirting with and teasing him. One evening I was napping on the couch, waiting for David to get home from work, when I felt something and woke up. Little Dave jumped up and went over to the lamp and switched it on. I asked, "Little Dave, what were you doing?" and was surprised that I didn't sound as scared as I felt. He said he was turning on the lamp. I said, "Before that," and he sat down next to me and said, "I'm very sorry, Amy, I was touching your breast." I had on a t-shirt with a low neckline. He said I was giving him mixed signals. I don't know how I was giving any signals in my sleep. He asked if I was going to tell David. I said of course I was, and I did. We couldn't kick him out, because he was paid up on rent, and we couldn't afford to buy him out. Besides, I had teased him before. I figured it was my fault as much as his. Now I'm not so sure. The next day, I went to his bedroom door and said, "Hey, man, if you ever touch my breast again I'll knock your teeth in. If you were anybody else, I already would have. Do you want Chinese?" That was pretty much the end of that, except now I can't nap on the couch in my own home. 

Kevin decided to get his own place, and David and I are doing likewise. Little Dave is moving into the dorms at his school. At my mom's suggestion, I took over the dishes entirely because I was tired of us arguing over whose turn it was. It gives me a sense of purpose. David and I went to the new apartments to look around and get applications. When I finally got up the nerve, we filled them out and the next day I walked down the road to turn them in. David had forgotten to sign something, so we faxed it to him at work and she ran our credit reports. We qualified with the minimum deposit. I was so proud of myself for handling business. When I was younger I was so shy I would have my little sister go up to the counter at Barnes & Noble to ask if they had a book.

I think I got a job. I called walmart every other day or so until I got an interview. When I got there they didn't know who I was. As I was leaving, a lady who had spoken to me said that the person I'd talked to on the phone just walked in and I should call personnel. I did and they told me to come back. I was glad because I hate to waste a good outfit and the dress shoes I'd bought in January seemed to get more painful each time I wore them and I had blisters on my heels. I had a great interview, and the lady asked if I could wait 15 minutes so they could do my second interview and send me for a drug test. I did, and they did. I walked (in cheap flip-flops I bought) almost a mile down Cobb Parkway and waited an hour to pee in a cup. They said they would call me for orientation on Tuesday, if nothing comes up in my background check or drug test. I'm going crazy.

my mom almost died. she was bleeding internally after her hysterectomy and it took the nurses five hours to realize something might be wrong. all told, she lost about seven units of blood. mom wasn't passing any urine post-op but she felt like she needed to go. she was also having trouble breathing. the nurses told her that the catheter would make you feel like you had to go, and the morphine could dampen your respiration. mom knows this. she says i saved her life because i told the nurses, "shouldn't she be peeing? she's had four cups of water and you've been pushing fluids through her i.v. for hours. where's the fluid going?" they looked thoughtful. finally. she wasn't able to urinate because her body was using all her fluids to make more of the blood she was losing. she had blood in her abdomen pressing against her bladder and her diaphram, causing her other problems. i was pissed at dama because she ditched me and Ly when it got rough and mom started screaming. i still am pissed, actually. i signed off on her second surgery to look for the bleed. she had two slow leaks. she was clinging to consciousness when they finally took her back. i was about to snap on some health care professionals. after her second operation, she looked like Jabba the Hut she was so bloated. the nurses couldn't figure out what was wrong with the monitor in mom's recovery room (the power cord was unplugged) and they wanted to know when she'd had her baby (she was in the maternity ward) and did not get that she was there for a hysterectomy. they kept asking her when she'd given birth until my dad said, "14 years ago!"

anyway, i found a sweater-jacket. today was the first day i thought it might be cold enough to wear it. and wasn't it! it was still trembling on the edge of darkness when i left the apartment. how the wind must love the gaps in loose-weave sweaters; it always seems so keen on penetration. usually, i end up wishing i'd left the extra bulk at home so i wouldn't now be carrying it; this morning i want to go back for longer sleeves on my shirt. 

i love the cold. there's a sort of giggling desperation in it: huddle close or we'll freeze! humans during the ice ages must have been very appreciative of ever their enemies in a storm. i wish we could love like that now.

the autumn always puts me in mind of magic and family and the falling away of everything not crucial. leaves leave. the wind wipes the slate clean. rains wash away memories of what has been. the old lends its strength to what will be, quickening in the womb of the earth. people talk of spring as the beginning of the cycle. i think death comes first. not in the macabre sense of Everything Dies, but in the realistic view that everything does, in fact, die- and that's absolutely necessary. following my great-grandmother's death, my mom (who was pregnant with my sister at the time) told me that people had to die to make room. fall never disappoints me.

once upon a time, my mom had a black eye. she told every one she hit it on the dresser. she hit it on my dad's fist. Ly has just learned this and is angry with mom for not having told her. when a kid's in shit, you never tell them how deep it is. mom didn't want her to have the fear that still sings in my nerves and makes me shrink from a raised voice and flinch when a hand comes near me. hell, mom didn't tell me how she got her shiner, and we were in the same foxhole. i suppose i might have guessed, but set it aside as knowledge that wouldn't help me. it bothers me how much my brain skipped over.

it's well i know that others have had it worse. dad didn't randomly wail on me. i had food, clothes, and shelter. i never slept in the garage. i was never molested. but when i was 3, holding my fork improperly or forgetting the "ma'am" or "sir" after "yes" or "no" were offenses punishable by a carefully controlled ass-bruising spank session. not beating, because i had done something wrong (i had the strong sense that dad was merely waiting for me to slip and forget my Manners so he could hurt me with impunity). always careful. that was a source of the fear: knowing that if he loosed that control, he could kill me. and i knew one day he would.

when we lived in the apartment in Jonesboro, the hall to my bedroom and bathroom had a door that, when shut, drowned the space in darkness. i was terrified of the dark, so putting me in the corner in this hall with the door closed and the light off was an ideal chastisement. i was obedient to a fault (i once called my mother from a birthday party to request the required permission for eating cake and ice-cream) so i sat facing the corner and sobbed. i was certain that Something Would Get Me and that i had dropped so low in my parents' regard that i was being offered up to this awful Something. i would emerge trembling, tear-stained, and later, hateful. i had seen my friends get in trouble and be embarrassed and guilty and even spanked, but none that i observed exhibited the trepidity and dripping fear that i felt.

so i got pissed.

in this way i reached the belligerence of my teens early. i didn't disobey purposely, but when confronted with a wrongdoing i hid my dread and reacted in a chilly, rational manner. and so my mind has ever been my escape route, my defense mechanism. i learned that one or two well-nuanced words could be stronger than my father's well-muscled arms. it all happened for me in that apartment. i grew up (or grew sideways) there, at the unripe age of 6.

when i was younger and i couldn't sleep, i would count sheep. 

it never worked.

my sheep wouldn't simply jump over the little picket fence.

they would do backflips. they would climb to the top of the fence and dive off to splash into the grass. they would lift up their little sheep skirts and gingerly step over the fence. they would look at the fence, look at me, and walk around the fence. they would climb through the fence and get stuck halfway, little sheep legs trying to walk on the air, until another sheep came and pushed the stuck sheep on through. they would get lost (much like my thoughts) on the way over the fence.

there were polka-dotted sheep, stripped sheep, plaid sheep, paisley sheep, rainbow sheep, sequined sheep, sheep in tuxedos, sheep in leisure suits, sheep wearing headbands and fringed leather jackets, sheep in glasses, sheep in evening-wear, sheep in jeans and Grateful Dead t-shirts, sheep in every color of the spectrum and a few colors beyond that.

i've been panicking so bad that my skin has been numb since last thursday. the numbness was gone this morning when i woke and i was so thrilled to feel my own fingers rub together that i nearly wept for joy. i'm terrified of doing poorly in classes and letting my bills lapse, and the fear paralyzes me, so i do nothing to improve my grades or finances.

also, i want to die.

so anything that grounds me in myself so firmly as school, work, or chores, seems threatening to my sense of self-preservation. because myself is who doesn't want to be. so i pretend to be elsewho. (which serves nothing in my real life.)

and what if i don't deserve to be better?

he allows me to be me without the pressures of actual life, but when i come home, i feel that much more alienated. so, do i stay as elsewho, or leave and be me, or do either and be myself?

does anyone give a shit what i choose? and should i? maybe it's time. maybe i've been here too long, a failed experiment taking up space.

i go to classes and to work.

sometimes it goes away and i can breathe and sing and think and be me.

it always comes back.
